video.title: Using Parcel Bundler with React
video.description:
Parcel is a web application bundler that offers blazing fast performance with zero configuration compared to webpack. In this video, we will create a basic React project using Parcel Bundler.

Tutorial from Nick Karnik. Check out his YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UClCm-WAOgN6XLwCpefSVezg

Nick on Twitter: https://twitter.com/theoutlander

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: rct999
VisualFutureOfMusic
topLevelComment.text:
I got a dependency resolution error. The only difference I saw between my and your environment was the use of pnpm in place of npm, which (also following your suggestion to install parcel-bundler at both global and local scopes) I thought might be impacting it's behavior. Hence, your package.json contents at the time of calling "parcel src/index.html" would have been helpful.

(As it turns out, I had to install and import 'prop-types', as these appear to have been transferred out of the original react package - and which subsequently worked. See:

https://reactjs.org/blog/2017/04/07/react-v15.5.0.html#migrating-from-react.proptypes)

topLevelComment.text: Hello,  i have a problem (\src\index.html: URI malformed) , you now how fix it? Sorry for my english)

topLevelComment.author: Les
topLevelComment.text: What vscode extensions do you use or recommend?

replies.author: Nick Karnik
replies.text: Les I’m using Webstorm in this video. I haven’t customized VSCode much so I’m not sure if there’s an extension to make it look like WS. It would be a good one to create :). In my newer videos where it’s just the client side, I use CodeSandbox.io.

topLevelComment.author: Bryce Kilker
topLevelComment.text: This was really helpful. Thanks!

topLevelComment.author: Mateja Petrovic
topLevelComment.text: Parcel is an amazing tool especially for newcomers because they can get a react app up and running in seconds! It really makes the whole process faster, more approachable and enjoyable. With everything taken into account Parcel can have a great impact on developer happiness.

topLevelComment.author: Vedran Mandić
topLevelComment.text: "Make webpack obsolete..." that was bold :/

topLevelComment.author: Abhishek Kumar
topLevelComment.text: Thank u for this awesome video

topLevelComment.author: Ephrey Ilunga
topLevelComment.text: Please,  is PARCEL equal to Webpack ? Or can I really use Parcel instead of Webpack ?

replies.author: Ephrey Ilunga
replies.text: Nick Karnik  thank you ! That is exactly the answer I needed. Appreciate that !

replies.author: Nick Karnik
replies.text: Ephrey Ilunga  I'm not sure if I understand the question correctly, but I'm going to attempt to answer it. My suggestion is to search for the parcel-bundler github issue tracker and go through active issues (if you are curious about known issues). However, my recommendation is to just try Parcel and get a feel for it. I am not keeping up with their issues so you won't hear from me about it. Hope that answers it.

replies.author: Ephrey Ilunga
replies.text: Nick Karnik  , thank you for your quick reply ! I will definitely try it out and see how it works for me. One last  question, how will I be noticed when you will found out the web sockets issue came from and sort it out ?

replies.author: Nick Karnik
replies.text: Hi Ephrey! Parcel is definitely ready to be considered a replacement for Webpack, IMO. I've used it in about 20 projects of various sizes so far for various clients and we haven't had any issues. Once a student of mine had ran into an issue related to web sockets, so I would recommend checking their issue tracker to see if something stands out. Either way, you should experiment with it to see if it works for you. It will take less than 10 minutes.

topLevelComment.author: Fabrizio Tofanelli
topLevelComment.text: This video is amazing! For some reason, I wasn't going for Parcel field, but now, I'm more than convinced to use it every day =)
